text:
Bottle:
Black....with a small beige head.
Smoky molasses, bitter chocolate aroma.
Taste is earthy, woody, roasty malts...peaty...
Solid....and then some....nicely dry.

Bottle. Oak, molasses, chocolate, roasted barley malt, and dry hay aroma - great. Black with moderate tan head. Moderately sweet molasses, chocolate, roasted barley, and mildly bitter hay flavor. Decent body. A great stout.
12 ounce bottle from Binnys. Peat and smoke in nose and initial taste. Light chocolate roast body. Ok.

Pours a deep brown with a creamy looking and long lasting darker tan head. A balanced aroma consists of earthy malts, chocolate, peat, lighter coffee, and some smokiness. The taste has plenty of peat with a smokiness that dominates, though it isnt overpowering. Faint coffee is found as well as some earthy impressions. Aftertaste is a lingering smokiness. A light to medium body, thinner in texture, with some softer, fizzy carbonation. This is a pretty good stout.

this one is a rough one..strong licorice flavor to start with a smell reminiscent of my dentists office. roasted malts dominate this stout. pours reddish dark brown in color with a tan head. had at world of beer

Das Bier im Glas tiefschwarz mit beigem, sehr stabilem und grobporigem Schaum. 
Im Antrunk ist das Bier leicht rauchig-säuerlich. Nicht so dickflüssig wie erwartet, eher schon an der Grenze zum Wässrigen. Der Hauptteil ist leider recht körperlos, angenehme rauchmalztöne zusammen mit Espresso-Kaffeenoten und dunkler Schokolade - aber alles sehr verhalten und nichts wirklich charakteristisch. Sind die hier nicht in der Lage, bei 5,5% ein vernünftiges körperreiches Bier zu brauen? 
Der Nachgeschmack ist dominiert von einer sehr wässrigen Grundnote. Die tollen Stout-Aromen wagen sich kaum hinter der dicken Wasserschicht hervor, das leicht rauchige Röstmalz schafft es gerade so eben, sich noch etwas länger als das Wasser im Mund zu halten. Auch eine ganz leichte Herbe ist jetzt wahrnehmbar. 
--> richtig enttäuschend!! Alle Aromen vorhanden, mit denen ich dem Bier ohne Probleme 15 Punkte geben würde - wäre da nicht dieser dominant wässrige Körper, der alle tollen Aromen im Ansatz ertränkt! 
Leider schon wieder ein Beispiel misslungenen amerikanischen Bieres! Schade! 
Trotzdem vielen Dank an Chris für dieses Bier!!


(5.4.2011) --> 	Noten: 12,6,10,3,1,6 - 6,50

Pours a nice deep brown with a solid tan head. Smells a bit smoky, earthy, very much like dirt. Some caramel. Taste is earthy toasted malt, some moderate smoke flavor, and a caramel finish with an earthy bitterness.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Dark brown and tan head. Delicious roasted aroma and hints of the smoked malt. Very tasty dry stout, the smoked malt adds a great dimension to the flavor. Dry, not too heavy but very good.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Backlog of ratings. Thanks to someone at one of bu11zeyes tastings. The smell is malts, roast, toast, and ok. The look is brown to black in color, thinner tan head, and dark. The taste is oily malts, chocolate, sort of smooth, and more roast.
Bottle. Pours dark with tons of roasted malts on the nose. Some bitter chocolate, most roasted malts and a nice amount of peat defines the flavor. Pretty thin palate, solid beer.
Rated in 2010 (Backlog) - Deep brown in color with a small beige head. Aroma is of peat, smoke and roasted malts. Taste is of peat, smoke and dark chocolate.
Aroma is dark fruit, roasted malts, coffee and a small hint of smoke.  The flavor is dark fruit, roasted malts, coffee, mild but lingering smokiness and a mildly tangy/acidic finish.

Pours a dark brown with a decent bit of tan head that doesnt stick around for too long. Aroma is heavy on the roasted malt. What sets it apart from others of the style is the hint smokiness in the aroma. The taste follows quite well. The sweet cream of the taste is complimented well by the subtle overtones of smokiness that arent overpowering but make for something different. The finish is a bit astringent due to a bit of salt and the roastiness 

Overall a pretty good stout. Would definitely enjoy again soon

Smoky roasted aromas, creamy mouthfeel with a slight malt sweetness in the flavor. A solid Porter would drink again. Most defiantly the smokiest dry stout I ever drank. If you dont like smoked beers stay away
UPDATED: NOV 17, 2012 Brown with tan head. Smoke, chocolate, and cappucino, with salt notes. Creamy but not heavy. Definitely one to keep an eye out for. I know of no better dark beer in Wisconsin.
Not as heavy as I expected but still a full bodied feel.  Very smooth.  Smokey and delicious.

Near black with a thick mocha colored head. Smells smokey, like peat, tabacco, dry, and roasted malts. Mild sweetness that is dry and quickly fades. Medium body with a creaminess. Decent, would go great with a cigar or a steak.

On tap at Old Fashioned, pours black with a thin tan head, the aroma has a good amount of milk chocolate and some caramel, the flavor has a bitterness of chocolate on the front end with a hop kick in the finish, overall pretty balanced and nice.

Nice roast with distinct peat. Black.with white brown head. Interesting roast with an immediate pea5 coming through. Nice creamy and dry. Very good. Favorite for style for me. Good chocolate in flavor and nose.

Pours rich and velvetty with a tall dense mocha head.
Aroama is rich and malty with nuiances of earthy peat at the end.
A good tasting stout with a big dose of roasted malts and smokey peat.
Smooth and semi dry finish. Me likes.

On tap at the Old Fashioned in Madison, WI., and dispensed to a shaker a little on the cold side, with an opaque, black/brown color, cream & bubbles, brownish tan head foam, and impressive, curtainy lacing. The aroma was roasty, some woodiness and char, maybe a little creamy flake, and earthy, barnyard scent. The flavor was similar, and contributed a lingering, medium hop bitterness, and an additional leathery character. The body was medium+, and the finale was bitter and dry. Interesting recipe, but for me, it was a little difficult to finish.
Nice, sweeping smoke and dark cocoa. Fairly dry finish. Worth getting if see on tap.
Pours dark brown with a tan head.  Aroma is smoke, roast and dark chocolate.  Taste is sweet with a drying finish.  Very solid, easy to drink.
From a bottle poured a brown color with a good amount of head.  Smokey malty flavor with a lingering finish.

Bottle.  Deep, dark brown in color with a small khaki head.  Aroma has chocolate, slight peat, cream, slight caramel.  Pretty nice.  Peat is much more prominent in the taste.  Upon first sip it is the strongest flavor.  Bitter chocolate, roasted coffee, cream all present in the flavor.  Fairly thin, though.

Pours a dark reddish-brown color with lacy mocha-colored head. It has a pleasant roasty aroma with lingering notes of smoked peat. Light to medium body with a distinct dryness on the finish. The taste is sweet with a slight bitterness on the finish. Flavors of peat, smoked malt, caramel and dash of hops. Very sessionable stout. Im sure it would be great on nitro.
Dark brown with a tannish head. Smoky aroma. Very smoky flavor with roasty malt underneath. Deep and flavorful with a light finish. The low alcohol makes this very drinkable as well.
Thanks Tomtheg for the hookup.  Smoke and other stouty flavors.  Not good, not worthy of my cash thats for sure.

Thanks to the kind soul at the last Tampa crew tasting that opened this one.  Pours a dark brown with a tan head.  Nose is roast, peat, smoke, earth, and unsweet chocolate.  Flavor is similar with peat, roasted malt, and earth with smoke throughout.  Medium in body and peat all over.
Bottle into a pint glass.  This was my first time trying out a stout-rausch and I really enjoyed the combination of flavors.  The smokiness and the stout coffee tastes complimented each other nicely.
Pours a dark brown which lets a tiny amount of light through. The nose detects the peated smoke smell which is quite pleasant.

Bottle pours deep brown/black with a tan head. Aroma shows roasted malt, peat, chocolate, and smoke. Flavor shows the same with additional coffee and indiscriminate dark fruit. Overall body is moderate to full, dry, and finishes with a roasted/smoked bitterness.

Pours an opaque black with a crown of thick creamy brown foam. Nose is of malt with a hint of smoke. Very creamy on the palate, strong taste of smoked peat, dark roasted malt carmel and pepper assault the taste buds. This beer is packed with flavor. Stands alone as a banquet itself or can be paired with bbq ribs, pulled pork sandwiches or ribeyes or burgers off the grill.
Bottle thanks to Beerman6686. Pours black. Tan head. Nose/taste of peat, smoked black malt, chocolate and light BBQ. Medium body. Smoked BBQ finish.

Pours dark brown.  Roast malt and light smokiness in the nose.  Nice round roast flavor that lingers slightly.  Barely a hint of smoked malt in the background.  Very even carbonation.  No offending roast aspects.  Just a simple, good stout.
Not the worlds greatest Stout. Its a very solid taste, and a beer that you could easily drink one after another after another after...

Bottle courtesy of BeerFMAndy. Served in a Hill Farmstead wine glass.

Pour brings forward a beer that is nearly black and has a thin tan head. Some spotty lacing and not so great retention, though theres a thin collar throughout. The nose brings a bit of coffee alongside a strong base of roasted malt. The flavor is a bit more complex, adding in some dark chocolate alongside the dark, dark coffee. Roasted malt is dominant and becomes a bit too dry and bitter in the finish. Pretty solid effort; Id have this again.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 05-18-2011
UPDATED: JUL 2, 2013 This is one of the most  unique tasting stouts I have ever tested. The peat smoked malt really does it for me.

Bottle: Poured a dark black color stout with a nice brown foamy head with good retention and minimal lacing. Aroma of light smoke peaty malt with roasted coffee notes. Taste is a great mix between some peat malts with notes of roasted coffee and a light touch of black chocolate. Body is about average with good carbonation. Love the light smoked peat notes on that one.
Dark cola color with minimal head that fades quickly. Has a pleasant smokey roast flavor to it.

12 oz bottle from Casanova Liquors (Hudson, WI). Pours a very dark blackish hue, some good haze, ruby bottom and some on the edges, but pretty dark overall, with a decent frothy light brown head, dies to a good layer, laces ok. Aromas are roasted malts, toast, and soda bread, some touches of coffee, a touch of smoky ash, more roasted barley, dry. Initial is medium bodied, dry and roasty up front, with good toast, bread, biscuits, soda bread, toffee, and coffee. Into the middle we get some peaty smoke, ashy and peaty, earthy smoke with some touches of toffee sweetness. Really quite dry and roasty overall, a bit heavier on the palate than Im used to from the Dry Stout category. I like the peaty smoke, it give sa unique feel and as a Smokehead I appreciate it. Lingering on into the finish, dry roast, peaty smoke, wood, ash, and touches of sweetness peeking through. If anything it loses itself a bit in its identity, but the uniqueness of a peaty smoke push towards dominance is quite pleasant, albeit a bit big on the palate. I liked this, I wouldnt drink it all the time but it certainly was unique. Aromas was lacking, appearance was good, flavors were very nice, and it might have been a touch too dry, but thats just me nitpicking.

12 oz bottle from Sonoma WI....pours black with decent head and nice lacing...aroma is dominated by the peat / smoky nose; not my cup of tea put it grows on you....nice body....taste mellows as it warms....
Very dry, smoky and roasty flavor - less sweet than any stout Ive tried before. Interesting, unique flavor. Very dark brown in color, with a huge light brown head.
Probably the best irish dry stout i have had, and that isnt saying much. IT is light with a hint of roastiness.

Source: 12 oz bottle from local retailer

Aroma: Smells like a lot of dry stouts Ive had in my day. Just a wee bit of bittersweet chocolate comes through to the nose. Quite pleasant, actually.

Appearance: For all intents and purposes, this beer is is an opaque black. It pours with a fingers width of khaki colored head.

Taste: Not nearly as bitter as I was expecting. In fact, this stout is quite sweet for a "dry" stout (a very strong chocolate taste to it, slightly lighter caramel notes). Got the lovely malty backdrop I like in a stout of this style, but the unusual sweetness is the star attraction.

Palate: Pretty smooth on the palate. Has a moderately thick body to it. None of the flavors linger too long in the mouth.

Overall: An excellent offering from Furthermore. The sweetness of the beer was a bit surprising, but very welcome. One of the best dry stouts Ive ever had.

Tasting at Pauls house.  The aroma is smoke, chocolate, brown sugar, very nice.  The appearances is a slighly translucent brown, light btan head.  The flavor is smoke, chocolate, roast - enjoyable, and not overly dry.  The finish is smoke again, meaty, pine, resin.  Medium/thick in body, particularly for an Irish stout.  Enjoyable.
Draft.  Pours dark blackish brown with off-tan head.  Nose is dark malt, chocoff.  Tastes black malty, with cacao, coffee, slight rauchy notes, backup hops, and a decent complexity.

Pours a dark black with foamy light brown head.  Aroma is sweet baking chocolate with slight lactic notes.  Flavor nice and dry yet somewhat creamy.  Not too bitter or overpowering, yet still has depth.  Dry roasty finish.  Overall, dangerously drinkable.
Pours black with a tan soapy head.  Aroma of smoke, plums, and wood.  Smoky flavor with peat, and plum sweetness.  Dry as advertised.  Nice beer.
Pours a dark brown with small tan head.  Smell of smoked peat is strong.  Taste is subtle but gets more smoky as you get into it.  Nice smooth beer.

Appearance: dark black with burnt edges. Fluffy khaki head fades rocky with big bubbles mingling amidst mousse-like meringue. Lingers in the shape of a doughnut. Mahogany highlights along bottom. Swirls with khaki clumps and tons of lace.

Nose: smoke, wood chips  cedar comes to mind, burnt wood esters, and dry brittle bakers chocolate chunks. Faint plums and prunes in the back; sweetness of meats then bitter nip of the skins. Black root and black strap molasses mingle with the earthen smoky burnt essence.

Palate: medium mouthfeel and weight with a prominent burnt bitterness. Burnt wood, peat, smoke, and some nicely aged cedar. Dry finish with smoke in the breath. Black root, more wood, black strap molasses charred and tastefully crusty. Brittle chocolates in the back of each quaff. Plum skins linger long with the subtle bitterness found only in the very end while plum meats tantalize along with a sweet chewy dark raisins in middle quaff.

Final Thoughts: if you dont like peat and you dont like smoke then you very well may not like this beer. By all means though, dont let that stop you from trying. I love both so of course I enjoyed the heck out of this beer. Thanks sis!

In short: A competent stout with a dominant black coffee flavor.  Good 
How: Bottle 12oz.  Split three-way
The look: Dark brown body topped by a very small beige head
In long: Nose is a bit roasted with lots of black coffee notes of cigarette butt.  Taste is roasted crunchy malts, brownies, a cup of black coffee, some tobacco, some cacao, light peaty notes.  A fun beer.  According the the description This is our rendition of a Dry Irish Stout, circa 1890 , people were drinking good beer back and didnt worry much about the 1.9K bug.

(12oz bottle thanks to JJFoodie)  Lots or aroma- smoke, minerals, roast, limestone. A good amount of smoked salmon. Very nice smell. Black color. Taste is about the same as the smell, very complex and full- Smoked salmon, minerals. A nice beer.

Potent, smoky, caramel roasty,  aroma.  Pours a dark, dark brown with a healthy, foamy head.  Heavy taste, emphasizing a smokiness, and coffee like.  Body is lighter than a stout, but it is full flavored and very unique.  Tasty stout, definitely worth a try, as its nothing like Ive had before.

12 ounce bottle thanks to Kevin. Pours a dark chestnut color with a medium light brown head. A nose full of peat and smoke, caramel as well. The flavor is sweet and smooth; caramel, smoke, lightly roasted malts. Smooth and nice. The peat stands out. Very good.
Dark brown with a small off-white head. Aroma of chocolate and caramel with a band-aid note. Dry and thin chocolate flavour with a touch of peat smoke.

12oz bottle. Briess trip leftovers from the look of it. Pretty thick black with a tan head that has good retention. Chocolate aroma with a touch of under ripe bell pepper hat could be the peat. A bit earthy and sharp. The flavor has a big sweet caramel component that almost overwhelms the roasted flavors. A bit vegetal and earthy. Medium bodied. I wasnt really compelled to finish this.

Bottle shared by Kyle, thanks! Poured black with a light brown head that dissipated to the edges. Aroma was quite smokey with plenty of roasted malt. Flavor was slightly dry with roasted and smoked malt and a bit of coffee.. The beer was a bit thin for my liking.

Pours a deep brown color with a medium brown head. The aroma is mildly smoky and earthy with plenty of chocolate notes. The flavor is very earthy with a nice smokiness throughout and a good chocolate character. There is a very nice level of hop bitterness in this beer as well.

Dark brown almost blackish color with a bit of tan head.  VERY  smoky malty aromas which are even more potent in the flavor.  Definitely  dry in the mouthfeel, and surprisingly light considering how dark and rich the flavors are.

Not my favorite style, but this is a tasty brew, and something I would definitely drink again.
Bottle. Pours a clear and dark brown beer with a beige head. The aroma is malt and peated smoke. The flavor is malt, peated smoke and caramel. The palate is dry. Overall an average beer.
Pours dark brown with a beige head. Aroma is roasted malt, peated smoke and light chocolate. Flavour is roasted malt, peated smoke, chocolate and coffee.

(12oz bottle thanks to JJFoodie) deep brown pout with khaki bubbles. Nose of bandaid, roasty. Taste is roasty, sweet nuts, cooked green peppers, with a medium thick creamy body and linger of dry cocoa on the palate.
Bottle @ J.C.G US Tasting, Pt 3. Pours black with a creamy head and lacings. Nose is vague roast, smoke and fruit. Dry and bitter roasted end. Smooth palate.

(12oz bottle, courtesy of jjfoodie)  Pours a dark mahogany body with a medium beige head.  Aroma of smoke, roasted malt, and some chocolate.  Flavor of beef broth, green pepper, smoke, chocolate, and roasted malt.
bottle, thanks to jjfoodie, walnut brown pour with bubbly foam, straight caramel aroma, flavor has good smokiness, oily, malty toffee

bottle thanks to jjfoodie.  poured black with a cream head.  nose is roasted malts, smoke, faint chocolate, and coffee.  nice on the palate, flavor is roasted malts, peat, light smoke, and a roasty finish.

Thanks to jjfoodie for sharing this bottle.

The beer pours a dark brown color with a tan head. The aroma is earthy hops with some toffee, chocolate and nuttyness. The flavor is toffee with quite a bit of smoke. The smoke was a surprise since I didnt get any of it in the aroma. Medium mouthfeel and medium carbonation.

bottle thanks to allendodd.  Pours dark brown/black.  Not much head.  Aroma of smoke, toffee, coffee, dark malts, sugar, hay, some vanilla.  Nice bitter start, understated smoky malt flavor.  Good beer.

A very solid dry stout - the addition of the peat smoked malt gives it a strong, earthy, smoky character that lends itself well to the dry, roasty qualities of the beer - it is fitting that there are roots on the bottle, because the beer tastes of the soil - a lot of dry cocoa character arrives late, and lasts through the finish - long finish of smoke and wood - really nice.

Bottle:  Very dark brown pour with a thin brown head.  Roasty and chocolatey aroma gives the impression of a dry, smokey, and ash laden roast.  Taste is more roasty, smokey, and burnt malt.  Ashes.  Some espresso.  Peat malt, as per the description.  Fits their bill and good for the intentions.

Sampled from a 12 oz brown bottle this beer poured a black color with a large brown head that lingered and produced good lacing. The aroma was woody, smoky and roasty. The flavor was dryish, woody and smoky with notes of tasty malts, vanilla and a touch of rum. The finish was medium length dry, roasty and woody. Medium body. Solid.
aroma is obscured chocolate and pretzel malt.  appearance is opaque with oil slick head.  flavor is sizzling bitterness, more dry pretzels and unsweetened cocoa.

Bottle pours a near black with a medium tan head.  Aroma is heavy on roasted malts, smoked malt, chocolate, and coffee. Taste is chocolate, coffee, with a hint of smoked malt in the finish.  Body is medium-heavy but still easily drinkable.  When I see peat malt being used in a beer it tends to make be nervous but Furthermore did a great job on this one.

Pours deep brown/black with tan head, aroma is peat, roasted malt, and some bitter chocolate.  Taste up front is chocolate, peat, smoke, finishing with some coffee and bitter roasted malt notes.  Good brew, balanced and drinkable.
Draft. Dark pour with tan head. Roasty malts, is pushing it, this stout is boring, has little flavor or aroma, however there isnt anything bad with this its just kinda flavorless.

Enjoyed from a 12oz bottle in a pub glass.  The beer pours a very deep brown to black color, with a small to moderate tan head.  The nose gives initial characters of toffee and dark chocolate, along with a bit of caramel; more than one would expect in a dry stout.  As the sample warms, more smoke character becomes apparent, although not to the point that it could truly be considered a smoked beer.  The palate replicates many of the noses advertisements, especially with regard to the nice interplay of caramel, toffee, and roasted character.  Hop bitterness or flavor is not obviously detectable.  The finish is fairly dry, fairly smokey, and fairly clean.  Overall, a very nicely done and complex example of the style.

Big black pour with a creamy very thin head. Slight roasty aroma. A very tasty stout initially, all the desired dark beer flavors. Good crisp carbonation for a dry baby. Comes across more alky than 5.5%.  Oh yes, quite burnt and bitter at times but certainly not over  the top.  Above average fer sure. Notsure if I really taste any peat in there or not, just a bad ass stout without going impy on ya.  This is new around here and was glad to have had the chance to taste it. Got it at 3 sons. Yep, the peat is not real apparent, just seems real stouty.
user_location: Beaver Valley, Beaver County, Pennsylvania, USA

text: A delicious and smokey stout. Aroma was pretty good. Deep dark roasted malt with a slight earthiness to it. Pour was a nice deep dark brown/near black with a one finger tan head. Taste was very full. Strong roasted malt with a deep peaty smokiness that made the beer very unique and delicious. You could classify this beer as a smoked beer as easily as a dry stout. Excellent strong carbonation. Will buy again
user_location: Moon Twp, suburb of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, USA

text:
Bottled. First impressions were very good, though things have dropped off a little bit as it warmed. I tried to pair this with a Five Spice Pork noodle dinner but it didnt quite pair up, so this ended up warming a bit much. There is quite a bit of campfire, peaty smoke in the aroma, with a hickory and chimney-like quality to it. Further inspection yields sea salt, caramel, and marshmallow. No astringency to be found, and little roast. In the aroma, this comes across more as a smoked than a stout.

Flavor is pretty bright, milky, with a lightly sour finish, in the best English traditions. Decent body, well integrated carbonation, with a carbonic finish. Overall a nice, smoky stout, though the Dry Stout categorization seems a bit off, at least as we brew them today.

This poured a very dark brown color with a fluffy beige head.  Aroma was very dry, some roasted coffee and dark chocolate, but they were hard to pick out. Flavor was very dry, no sweetness at all, just deep roasted malts, and smokey chewing tobacco. Great dry stout.

I had know idea who, where or what Furthermore Three Feet Deep was until I studied the label, drank the beer and looked them up through links on RB.  Small brand contract brewed in Wisconsin that has made its way to the Philadelphia area.   Deep full bodied Irish style Dry Stout with a smokiness that mates well with coffee, chocolate, roasted malts.    Well done, unique, hope to try more of their beers.

12 oz bottle.  Pours a flat black body with a one finger fizzy light brown head that faded to a thin covering.  I love the nose, theres a nice peat smoke level over a dry roasty malt base.  Some light coffee, bakers chocolate, and some briney notes.  Based on the nose Id say this could pass for a Smoked beer.  The flavor is rather aggressively smoky, much more so than I was expecting.  Its not crazy smoky, but its clearly the dominant flavor.  Roasty and chocolaty below the smoke, this really hits my sweet spot.  I wish the body were a little thicker and softer though, it is a bit watery on the finish.  Overall its pretty darn great, I wish I would have picked up a sixer of this one.
Rating from memory, but thought it was a decent if not very memorable stout with some roasted malt and chocolate.  Cant remember much else.

12oz bottle, no dates.  Deep dark brown, light tan foam with decent retention and zero lacing.  Aroma is mostly DMS and if I squint real hard maybe some cocoa.  Mostly sweet flavor, caramel malts, DMS and just a little bit of peat hidden way under the mess.  These beers need rescued from the contract brewer, good recipes gone bad.

12oz. Bottle:  Aroma of dark malts, roasting, light chocolate, band-aids, light chocolate, slight peat, and a hint of smoke.  Poured very dark brown in color with a large, creamy, rocky, brown head that diminished but lasted throughout.  Cloudy. Opaque.  Some particles.  Very good lacing.  Flavor is lightly sweet and light to medium bitter.  Tastes of dark malts, roasting, Bamburg wood, smoke, light chocolate, and a hint of caramel.  Medium body.  Slightly dry texture.  Average carbonation.  Bamburg wood, light chocolate, and roasted malt finish.

12 oz bottle from Capones. Poured a deep dark black that was slightly thin and an average bubbly light beige head. Aroma was nice with lots of peat smoke, molassess, dark corn syrup, cola and dry toast. The palate is overly bubbly and the body is thin and liquidy for a stout. The flavor has lots of hickory smokey sweetness about it along with dry toast and some dark roasted malts. Not bad but Ive had better from Futhermore.

Black pour with a medium tan head.
Aroma is smokey, earthy roasted malt. some chocolate. 
smokey roasted malt flavour with a light bitterness.

12oz bottle.  Opaque black with  thick beige head.  Smoky and creamy, with a solid sandy hop bitterness in the background.  Big chocolate presence as well, think Chocolate Cream Dry Stout.  Mellow, chocolate milkshake finish.  The peat smoked malt adds a nice dimension to it, making it slightly reminiscent of Old Chub smokewise.  A great modern Stout.
Bottle. notes of coffee, a lot of smoke, beef jerky, peat, dirt.  Smokier than expected.  Tastes like smoked cool coffee.  Good, not great, beer.
Bottle.  Dark brown.  Tan head.  Sweet aroma with chocolate, roasted malt, vanilla and a hint of smoke.  Flavor is malty and has a bit of coffee with chocolate and the smoke too.  Nice.

Bottle - Furthermore just keeps coming through for me with their small, but quality lineup. Three Feet Deep pours black with a foamy tan head. Smells sweet and earthy, with a little milkiness and sweet chocolate. Taste starts with just a hint of whiskey, then smoke, bitter coffee and chocolate, and roasted malt. It has a nice warming finish and feels medium-bodied and smooth. Dont know much about peat, but this beer educated me. Great stuff.

12oz bottle.  Pours a deep black with a thin espresso head.  Aroma is appropriately stout-ish, with roasted malt and coffee along with hints of peat, vanilla, and smoke.  Taste is full and dry, with an initial flavor of peat, smoke, and roasted malt hitting hard before a mellow aftertaste of tobacco and bitter coffee.  This actually reminds me more of a nice blend of pipe tobacco than scotch, in an odd way.  Whatever it may be, its a fun twist on a stout.
BOTTLE: jet black pour, aroma of smoke and roasted malt. Mmmm. Taste is also roasty, smoky, and theres a couple layers of flavor as this one goes over the tongue. Excellent brew.

2009 Bottle - Thanks Ughsmash! - Pours a thin almost black, with a slowly forming off white head...aroma is smoked grain and a bit of metal, dry malt...flavour is similar, heavy dry peat, bitter charcoal, more smoke...some tastes were a bit more enjoyable than others, cause this has more peat and smoke than most Scotch ales, which comes as medicinal every so often, but different none the less...
On cask for Firkin Fest at the Happy Gnome in St. Paul 09. Had a smoky aroma with medium roast.  Well balanced brew with some coffee and smoke in the flavor. Medium body also was nice.

Thanks to theisti for picking up this beer for me. Black pour with thin head. Nose is roasty, smokey peat with wood notes. Flavor is peaty, scotch with some nuts, grains and cocoa. Silk mouthfeel. Very nice. Thanks Tim.

From the bottle, pours black with a foamy off-white head.  Aroma is smokey.  Smells like your clothes the day after a campfire.  Taste is like eating the bark off your smores roasting stick.  Theres really not much more to say on this one.  Theres a bit of a malty character that sneaks in once the beer warms a bit, but that store-brand-charcoal-light-with-too-much-lighter-f still hangs in there.  Its decent, but its a bit too one-sided in flavor for me.

Impenetrably dark from the bottle. Can smell piat and rye, earth, coffee. Beige head that goes quickly. In the flavor, peat is right out front. Very smooth and smokey peat and coffee surrounded by hops - quite dry. I like smoked beer and I like peat and I like rye, so you know what how I feel! Actually, this beer could, for all of its outstanding effort, have just a bit more malt character: its a little thin. This brewer is very good, on a good track. This is a near world-class stout-porter. Keep it up.

UPDATED: JAN 5, 2009 Way underrated.  Bottle from Ed at Heritage.  Pours jet black with a pillowy tan head.  Smells a lot like DFH Palo Santo, brimming with wood chips and smoke.  Features more peat than the last three scotch ales I have had combined.  Flavors of barley, hazelnut, cream, and bakers cocoa are also present.  Silky mouthfeel.  Classic label.  Well done.

[Bottle] Pours a very dark brown color with a small tan head. Aroma of dark roasted malts and perhaps some cocoa. Taste is a little more earthy, with peat, light smoke and hints of coffee grounds as well. Better than average mouthfeel and low amount of carbonation. A nice twist on a rather common style.

Nice slightly smokey, roasty aroma. Taste is the same, but the smoke isnt overpowering, seems to be overtaken by the malt. Some coco and coffee aspects in there as well. Nice to have an affordable sixer available year round.

12 oz twist off bottle purchased at Zipps in Minneapolis, Minnesota. Pour is black with ruby highlights and a pretty one inch dense khaki head. Falls slowly to reveal lacing. Aroma of peaty moss roastiness. Some bright pine hoppiness present. Taste is big peat moss initially, giving way to coffee roastiness and finishing with pine hop bitterness and more of the peat. Peat is really the main story here, and it is quite expressive. Creative beer. Palate is medium to thinnish, drinkable.

Thanks to TheISTI for this brew. Pours very dark brown, pretty much black, with a smooth tan head. This thing pours and drinks like an imperial stout, very big flavor, powerful and bold. Massive roasty nose with smoked and earthy characters. Dark chocolate up front woody smoked finish.

Found this one canned at Dan’s Liquor in Plover, Wisconsin.  Dark brown pour with a thick, tan head, very smoky and molassassy with chocolate and coffee cloying for attention.  Nice and strong finish.  I’m surprised I found this one in the early Fall.

Very hazy deep mahogany with ruby highlights.  Some tan head.
Malty and nutty aroma.  Strong roastiness, some peatiness.
Roasty, nutty flavor.  Some metallic character.
Lingering cloying sweetness, lingering roastiness.  Hardly dry.

Bonused bottle from buckybeer.  Thanks dude!
Pours a nearly black color with a lasting light tan head.  Smell is roasted malts bordering on peaty smoky coffee.  Taste is dark, roasty but smooth malt, with not a big peaty smoky component, which I like.  A light bitterness balances it out.  Overall tastes pretty nice, and is very drinkable.  A bit drying in the finish.  Medium bodied and soft to medium carbonation.  Solid.

Bottle, straight-walled pint glass.  Pours an opaque black with a thick beige head.  Aromas of blackstrap molasses and dark chocolate.  First mouthful of suds tastes like earthy smoke balanced by a creamy mouthfeel.  Initial flavors are also of smoke, a little soy sauce in there, with a dry finish.  As the beer warms, it changes character, becomes somewhat sour and vinous, the earthiness is now like red beet, with a significant chocolate-bitter undertone.  As the head dissipates, mouthfeel becomes decidedly dry.

The pour is a really dark mahogany brown that shines slightly translucent when backlit.  A frothy tan head displays decent retention, leaving scant, sticky lines of lace on the glass.  The aroma is roasty, showing baker’s chocolate, scorched caramel, roasted barley, and fresh coffee.  An earthy hop bitterness is soothed by notes of lactic cream and dry nuts.  Flavors continue the dry and roasty theme.  Coffee, chocolate, and a touch of smokiness meet smooth cream and bitter woody notes.  Medium in palate with balanced carbonation, the finish is dry, with lingering roast.  This is a really nice brew, and its so easy to drink.  I enjoyed the twist that the smoked peat adds.

Black pour with a noisy violent tan head that lasts only a minute.  Nose is sweet roasted malt and smoke.  It is pleasant but restrained.  This is slightly acidic and offers a bit of hop.  It is full of roasted malt and milk chocolate with campfire smoke and some fruit.  A restrained beer but one that offers lots of good stuff.  Well crafted!

Deep black body, moderate head, some lacing. Flavor is richly flavored malt with a bit of smoke. Just a little bit sweet. Body is light for a stout. Finish is warm and makes for a craving to take another sip. This is good, a nice easy sipping session stout.

Pours a tar-like chocolate with tan tan tan head that dissipates to a bit of lacing. Aroma is of definite cacao and smoked meat. Malts are certainly present. Flavor is mellow malts and cacao. Traditional smoke flavor. I don’t feel it is anything too extraordinary there but it is a delicious beer. Body is a bit more thin than i expected for a beer of this style. The flavor is done well but a few other factors could stand tweeking.

UPDATED: DEC 25, 2010 bottle from stine 7/26/2009... pours a fairly opaque ruby brown/black topped by a dark hot cocoa colored head. some spotty lacing is left as it recedes. theres definitely smoke/peat on the nose... along with dry roasty grain, earth, grass, chocolate, some dark fruity sweetness and a coffee-like edge. nice soft mellow smokiness flavor mixes with chocolate, dry malty grain and a light acidic finish. ashy aftertaste. medium body seems a bit thin from the acidity and smoke. neat...7/4/7/3/16/3.7
bottle 7/12/10 straight from WI.

it smells and tastes like a compost pile mixed with chocolate, ashy roast, toasted nuts, caramel and coffee. really quite warming in the belly. 8/4/8/4/16/4.0
Poured black with a tan head. Aroma - coffee and smoke. Taste was smokey roast malt and coffee. Perhaps a bit thin.

Courtesy of tytoanderso. Fairly smoky aroma...lots of peat, some sweet roast malt and coffee. The body is full on black with a diminishing thumb thick tan head. Smoky fore, chocolate and coffee. Very peat/smoke driven. This is probably more of a smoked than a stout. Which means that I dont really like it that much, but it is well made.
dark brown with a slight off tan head. malty, earthy, sweet, and a good full mouth feel. the peat some thru as a lingering after taste/aroma. sweet label
[Bottle] Pours a clear deep brown with a medium tan head. Aroma is very smoky, with a bit of peat snuck in there. Peat/smoke overpowers most of the rest of the beer. Medium/thin mouthfeel.

Pours a dark red almost purple.  Got about 2 fingers worth of head from the pour.  Aroma is mild but you get a bit of roasted malt in there.  The first taste is earthy almost grainy.  To be honest, I have no idea what peat moss taste like but I imagine it is similiar to what you get in here.  You do get a smokey taste but it isn’t at all over powering.  If you are a fan of other smoked beers then you won’t be disappointed.  If however, you are like me and do not really go for smoked beers, you will find this is actually pretty pleasant.  The flavors are all there but not anyone over powering.  This is definitely worth a try.

Bottle Thinkin Bout Thirteen Hours O Drinkin (tew man wrecking crew) Pitch black ale with a small, frothy, beige head. Long lasting, creamy retention. The nose presents essences of chocolate, peat smoke and coffee with a lesser note of wood. Full-bodied and silky with modest carbonation. Light sweetness, smoke and moderate acidity. Roasted, smoky, lightly acrid finish. Thanks go out to SoLan for sharing this one!

Courtesy SoLan.  Pours black, with a small, quickly dissipating light brown head.  Smells of light smoke and peat, subtle vanilla, and smoked wood in there as well.  The flavor was a little heavier on the smoke than the nose let on.  Very woodsy in its characters, with traces of harcoal, caramel malt, and roasty dark malts.  The finish had a small dose of hop bitterness as well which helped balance out that peat character.  I dug this.
This one pours a dark ruby color with a good head. There is a sweet smoke and cocoa in the aroma and flavor. Not bad.

Thanks to heemer for sharing at Swillfest 08
Smokey, peaty, tasty, nice brew

This dry stout pours a dark black color from a 12oz bottle. Medium sized beige foamy head. The aroma is chocolate, coffee and some smoke. A medium bodied stout. The malts are semi-sweet chocolate, coffee, some smoke and some peat. The hops are earthy. Kind of mellow tasting, there is a touch of smoke at the finish. Mouthfeel is full. Finish is clean and smooth. Aftertaste is slightly bitter.

This beer pours a completely black colour, as black as night you could say. Creamy malts with a touch of smoke in the aroma, not overwhelming. And even smokey in the finish. A deep rich mouthfeel, one of my favorites from this brewery.

thanks, heemer.  dark brown in color with red undertones with a tan head.  malty and scotchy but not as strong as i was lead to believe.  kinda watery, in fact.  but it does have a very smoky aftertaste.

Thanks tytoanderso!!  Bottle: pours very dark with a thin, bubbly head.  Aroma is peaty scotch, salty, scalded milk, with a smoked malt underlay.   Flavor is refreshingly smoky without being meaty, chocolate malts round out the palate.  Fades quickly in a hoppy, smoked finish.  Very nice offering.
user_location: I F&ckin hate those guys from, Ohio, USA

text: 12-oz. Thanks, Dodd! Pours black with a brief and shallow tannish foamy head that falls quickly to a slim tan rim, leaving generous sheets of lace as it goes. Nice mild semi-sweet chocolate nose. Medium, creamy body. Chalky, light sour milk, bittersweet chocolate on the mid-palate. Brief, mild chocolate finish.

Bottle thanks to CMUBEERMAN. Pours dark black brown, thin off white head. Aroma is smoky, meaty, earthy, salty. Flavor is the same. Very smokehouse with pineapple. Im loving smoky beers lately! Thanks so much Andrew!

Pours a dark brown color with tannish head.  Aroma is smoked peat, barnyard, light fruit and chocolate.  Taste is smoked peat with it coming somewhat close to a manure and hay smell.  There is also some light chocolate and sweet malt mixed in with a light fruitiness.  The carbonation is a tad high for a stout, but overall it plays out alright.  I would have thought Scotch Ale on this one instead of a stout.

Great looking deep dark body with a rocky brown head. Fruity sweet nose, no smoke. Maybe a little smoke in the flavor, but could be in my head. Sweet malt and a subtle sharp edge (hops, alcohol). A little too tame?

Bottled. A dark brown beer with a red shine under a brown head. The aroma is sweet malty with primary notes of over ripe fruit. The flavor is sweet mlaty again with primary notes of over ripe fruits, but also with a slight alcohol burn. Thanks yespr for bring this to Denmark.

12 oz bottle.  Dark brown with medium tan head.  Light aroma of smoked malts & chocolate.  Roasted malt sweet followed by a medium hop finish that leaves a chalky aftertaste.  A little weak for a stout.
Coffee, toffee, and burnt popcorn all come through, united by a common smokiness.  Drying, resinous aftertaste.  Body is a little thin.

deep impenetrable brown.  smoke, maybe coffee in the aroma.  smokey, smokey flavor with hints of coffee, chocolate.  even the finish is smokey.  but ultimatley, it was the lightness and sweetness of this brew that dissappointed me.

Pours an opaque black with a dark tan head and light-lacing.Aroma is lightly sweet, unsweetened chocolate and toffee. Flavor is a light dark caramel sweetness and some earthy hop bitterness. Lively carbonation, creamy texture, medium bodied. Finish is somewhat long, smoky and bittersweet. Overall a very decent dry stout.
Pours black with light brown head.  Definite peat aroma with a nice malty presence.  Flavor to match - lots of peat.  Definitely Irish.

I like the mix of the stout and smoke flaver.  Enjoyed this with a Packer Brat (Wisconsin chedder and sauerkraut.)  There was just enough smoke to get threw the heavier style of beer.  I will drink this on the ice tommorow.
My first "smoked beer" I really enjoyed it. Teh smoke hits at first and sloly disappears. Making this a very different and enjoyable beer.

12 oz. bottle.  Pitch black with a light brown, foamy head.  Aroma of smoke, roasted malt and mild coffee.  Flavor of dark roasted amlt and coffee with a dry, smoky bitterness.  The finish is dry with a smooth milk chocolate taste.  Light to medium bodied with more carbonation than I expected but still a good stout.
12 oz bottle from tytoanderso; nose of peaty malts with some light chcolate; opaque black with a medium tan head; flavor is chocolate and smoke with a coffee hint.

On tap at Stub and Herbs in Minneapolis.  The pint was dark colored with a light colored head and nice lace.  The aroma is roasty malt.  The flavor is chocolate and roasted maly - light smoke, perhaps peat.  The palate is medium rich and has a dry snap at the end.  Very nice.

Very nice smoky roasted malt with a light banana, bread dough, coffee, chocolate, and a hint of dark fruits.  Very nice dry finish with a hint of floral notes accompanying the chocolate and smokiness.
user_location: Farewell Minny; Hello Puyallup, Washington, USA

text: Black body with a light brown head. The aroma is mossy with some of that peat character. Its not a hint, its very up front. There is also some fresh bread dough. The taste has lots of smoked peat with some light hints of coffee and black tea. There is just a little bit of milk chocolate lingering in the aftertaste. A fairly thin body, but it seems right for this style. This is unique and I appreciate how Furthermore is continuing to stretch boundaries.

12 oz. bottle via trade with tytoanderso - Pours a dark brown color with a one and a half finger thick light tan head.  Nice lacing.  Aroma is smoked malt and faint chocolate.  Flavor is smoked malt, roasted malt and a touch of chocolate.  Palate is dry with a slight lingering roasted malt aftertaste.  Medium body.  A good beer. Thanks Tyler.
Pours a deep dark brown, with a light tan head. Light lacing. Aroma of smoky malts. Tastes of smoke and a sweet malt. A light hint of chocolate. A little dry on the aftertaste.
user_location: Mescal Lakes (wherever that is), Arizona, USA

text:
I think a lot of people are tasting this Dry Stout and expecting something sweeter, and then grading it down for not being a Sweet Stout.

Pour is black, with a thick light brown head.  Aroma is tar and smoke and asphalt.  Very clean on the mouth and in the finish, with some smoky peat in the flavor.  A nice balance.

This one pours black with a thick brown head.  Nose is asphaltic and coal tar.  Aroma is iodine and burnt wood.  Bitter with a surprisingly clean finish.  The peat overpowers much of this beer. but it makes a good winter sipper.  More of a Scotch ale.

12oz bottle-A dark black body with a small tan head which has an aroma of chocolate, roasted malt, and a very faint smoke aroma. A medium to full bodied brew with a taste of smoke on the front end followed by a great sweetness(chocolate) throughout till the end and the smoke kicks in again. The smoke is not overpowering. Nice tasting beer.
Bottle. Black pour with a tan head.Aroma of smoke, roasted malt, and dry chocolate. Flavors of smoke, roasted malt and bakers chocolate. Medium body, roasty/smoky/dry with a roasty finish.

Bottle.  A fairly simple, enjoyable stout.  Overwhelming roasted malt aroma with a hint of smoke.  Pours black with a very small amount of carbonation which leads to a minor frothy head.  The smoke flavor heads to the forefront of the palate upon tasting and lingers just a tad too long for my taste.

12oz bottle, no date.  Black with a 1/2 finger fizzy tan head, pretty decent retention after rousing it up a bit.  Lovely aroma of campfire and peated malt (usually I think these are one of the same, but I can pick out each of them here), and some roasted malts.  Not really picking up on any sweetness here, nor is it very complex, but so far, so good.  Flavor is much the same with a light caramel sweetness before the dry roasty char finish hits.  Medium body with light carbonation.  This was a good beer, but it seemed to be missing something.
user_location: Ocean Beach, San Diego, California, USA

text: Black color with a thick head.  Aroma of milk chocolate, roasted malt and smoke.  Strong malt and a significant whack of peat.  Very dry, but not really bitter at all.  Simple but quite tasty.

Bottle. [Courtesy of yespr, yet another great tasting @ Henrik´s] Average beige fizzy head that mostly diminished. Mahogany color. Spare lacework. Aroma of smoke, grain, roasted malt, caramel, fruit. Medium bodied with an average carbonation. Moderated sweet hint of bitterness. Smoke sweet finish.  18-09-2007

12 fl oz bottle. Pours deep brown with a lacing head. Dark roasted aroma, clearly smoked. Smoked flavour with an underlying roasted malt flavour. Just sweet enough without getting too much. Finish is slight dry malty. Nice.

(Bottle 35,5 cl) Courtesy of yespr. Clear, dark brown with a reddish hue and a light brown head. Fairly smoked aroma. Medium body with dry, burned malt accents and a distinct, smoked edge. The finish is dry but not very bitter. Quite interesting. 180907

Dark color. Light aroma of chocolate, with some roated malt. Dry mouthfeel, with a dry flavor of chocolate malt and roasted malt. Even if not my style, I have to say that its balanced and well brewed.

Bottle. Thanks to the person who sent me this, I forgot who it was. Pours a deep black body with decent head. Aroma is of roasted malt and a creamy scent to it. Flavor is slightly dry with a bit of smokiness to it. Roastiness and creaminess, smooth. Decent dry stout.

UPDATED: SEP 7, 2007 Dark Brown Color with Quickly Receding Tan Head.  Sweet Dark Malts, Bittering Roasts and Subtle Hints of Smoke Fill The Nostrils and Promises to be a Satisfying Stout. Heavy Bodied...Smoke Notes Initially Take the Stage...With Sweet Dark Malt Notes in the Background and Coffee Roasts Througout...,Bittersweet Dry Finish with an Overall Creamy Mouthfeel. Very Solid Stout. The Smoke Notes in the Afterstate Get a Pretty Solid Foothold on the Palate, So if Smoke is a Flavor You Enjoy, This Stout will be Wonderful

12oz bottle wife bought for me on her Wi visit. Dry coffee and coco aroma. Some sweetneas present as well. Black body with tan head. Flavor was sweet and more like cold coffee. Did have a creamy texture in the background but the carbination seem to hold it back. Sweet dryness on the palate decent brew.

It poured very dark with a lovely billowing head that, for a fleeting moment, looked to be turning into a Guinness-style cascade.  This was much better when it warmed significantly (near room temperature) than when cold.  When cold it was too hoppy and smokey; when it warmed it revealed some really nice chocolate, hazelnut, vanilla notes.  Well rounded flavors, good (though unremarkable) palate, and for the price its pretty good.
Bottle: Pours a dark brown with a creamy tan head. Aroma, peaty, smoky, with some chocolate. Flavor, light smoky notes, peaty, chocolate, coffee. Dry finish. Pretty solid.
Bottle. Near black pour with a small head. Smoky peat and roasted malt. The smoke seems a bit overpowering. I felt that it was covering other flavors. But it wasnt too bad as is.
12oz bottle. pours black with tan head. nose roast and smoke. flavor is roasty, sweet caramel. stale coffee, chocolate. mouth feel is watery and carbonation is fizzy. decent.

Surprisingly opaque black with a thin layer of cream skin.  A nose fit for a hunter.  Smoked prosciutto with maple bacon, hickory and milk chocolate. A mild but pleasant hint of Costa Rican light roast.  Silky.  Oceanic peat tones on the tongue, complemented by vanilla, coffee with  a lot of milk and sugar , or coffeecake.  Lactose dominates a bit with warmth.  A touch of citrus in a chocolate-orange sweetness.  Palate is rich, and a mite underdeveloped, vaguely lacking in nuance.  Well made, all said.  Underrated.

12oz bottle. Poured a deep brown color with an averaged sized tan head. Aromas of caramel, light chocolate, nuts, light smoke and peat. Tastes of smoke, roast, chocoalte, nuts, and a trace of coffee. The smoke came out more and more as it warmed up and as I drank more. Very good overall but the body was a tad on the thin side.

An above average but not great stout.  If not for the hint of peat, it would be fairly unremarkable, and the peat really is just a hint.  The nose has some nice toasty notes.  Good, solid coffee stout flavors, with the peat and some vaguely sweet milky notes coming in late.  Nice dry finish.  This might grow on me.

Bottle and served in a pint glass: Pour a cola deep brown with a mostly lasting beige head and some lace. The aroma is surprisingly nice with notes of English tobacco, smoked and peat malts,  light chocolate, licorice, walnut, grassy hops,  and mineral esters. The taste is not as powerful but for a dry stout it is more than your average flavor profile.  I really like how the smoke and peat sneaks into the finish after the basic stout malt notes are gone. I even got a hint of wood upon the aftertaste. The mouth feel is about the only place this beer is standard run-of-the-mill with an underwhelming thinnish body compared the flavor profile. I really dug this brew and vastly underrated IMO. I wish I had bought more bottles to share with others...okay Wisconsin raters, get the word out!

Bottled.  Poured very deep brown with rising carbonation and a very nice initial cap of deep beige head.  The aroma was just what I was looking for with deeply-roasted chocolates and well-integrated smoky peat.. I likes a little salty bacon with my chocolate!  Flavor was damn close, with a solid dose of deep roast, but less of the chocolate distinction.. again the peat stars and is very well executed.. dry-roasted cocoa and mild smoke linger for a medium-length finish.  Just shy of medium-bodied and dry as advertised on the palate.. decent flow.  Good stuff!

12 oz. bottle. Yeasty aroma features coffee notes and a sweet, chocolatey maltiness. The smoke smell is peaty and bacony, like a cross between a Scotch ale and a rauchbier (although much more subdued than a rauchbiers aroma). Pours an opaque black with a huge amount of grayish tan head. Produces extensive lacing. A smoke flavor dominates the taste, although it is subtle. The underlying strout is sweet and chocolatey, whereas I was expecting a dry, coffeeish, Irish-style stout. A light roasted coffee character does develop after multiple sips and in the finish. The taste is really good, but the flavors are not complex enough to earn a particularly high score (that is, if I could cull a couple more flavors out of this brew, I could have given it an 8 or a 9 for flavor). Surprisingly light, coffee-bitter aftertaste. Low in carbonation, despite the large head. Medium body. Smooth in the palate. Furthermore Three Feet Deep (thats a lot of "e"s!) unexpectedly ends up going the rauchbock route rather than the peaty, dry stout route, with a ham sweetness emphasized over a smoky, roasted dryness. I think the beer is better off for the choice, although Id argue that it is marketed inappropriately (see the commercial description above). This is a good start from a relatively new brewer. Im a sucker for a good smoke beer, and this definitely qualifies in that category.

Barely translucent and inky brown in color with a lasting, mossy and brown khaki head. The smoked nature hits the nose with toasted apple wood, flame struck brown paper bags and peat wrapped with brown sugar glaze. Some lactic milk chocolate pulls through to round out a well composed nose. Flavor slides in more lightly, with hard to ignore carbonation teaming with watered down mocha grinds and slightly scorched campfire twigs, the morning after the chocolate et marshmallow have abandoned the stick. Subtle smoky edges team with a Swiss chocolate bittersweet suggestive digestif. The carbonation pulls distractingly away from the flavor easement, but a hint of smoked espresso grinds keeps Three Feet Deep from going six feet under. Flame touched rubber chocolates see us through to the finish.
Pours a beautiful black with an extremely robust tan head. The nose is  quite smoky and roasty.  This carries through in the flavor as well...a nice variation on the style.

Dark brown to black with small lacing left behind.  A different smell right off the bat, as it has a acidic smell.  A dark roast coffee greats your first sip, lingering with the promised peat smoke at the finish.  A definate treat for Stout lovers, as this one will be a nice change of pace.

12oz bottle. Pours black with some nice creamy whitish/brown lacing and a small head to match. Nice aroma... like JK said, perhaps more of a smoke beer. Notes of dry cocoa, smoked malt, and yes... I think a hint of dried peat. Firm on the palate. Flavors of roasted malt, peat, cocoa, nuts all lead to a rather disappointing finish... a tad cardboard-y and watery. The finish distracts from an otherwise great beer. Points for ambition.

12oz bottle.  Almost opaque with a deep dark brown hue.  Ring of beige head.  Cocoa and vanilla aromas.  Nice malt aromas.  Medium to full bodied.  Smokey malt flavor followed by a bitter hopness.  The smokiness and the sweetness lingers long through the hops.  Cola dried dark fruit flavors.  Lively and zesty with a citrus acidity.  Mildly drying with coffee and chocolate bitter malty notes.  Meh?

Utterly black under slim roasted tan head.

Espresso and blackstrap nose...anise and pepper...roasty and dry. And smokey!

All that returns on the tongue, the cracked pepper, the earthy coffee taste, subtle bitterness. smooth, refreshing, but deep and serious, decidedly dry.
Full bodied, dry, bitter finish. 
And smokey!

Quite unique, actually, an interpretation unlike any Ive encountered lately.
(And smokey!)
Bit of whisper of whiskey in there, too. Hmmm...was that intentional, he muses sarcastically...

I would say this is a smoked.  There is significant smoked character in the aroma and flavor.  Smoky aroma witih light coffee.  Flavor has more smoked peat, with some coffee and dry malt.  Black color.  My first beer from Furthermore and I am impressed.  The low price is nice as well.
Dark black color with some small head.  Coffee aroma.  Nice smoky body to finish off the evening.

From a 12-oz bottle shared at JKs Spring Gathering, pours a near opaque black, with a small tan head. Aromas of sourdough bread, peat, raspberries, dark chocolate and some smoked citrus BBQ wood. Taste of dry roasted dark barley with a sweet aftertaste. Minimal hops character. Palate is smoky with a tangy finish.

Bottle thanks to Brigadier: Pours an opaque black with a lightly-lacing froth of dark tan head.  Has s lightly sweet, earthy dark chocolate nose with hints of toffee and peat.  First sip reveals a mild dark caramel sweetness, some earthy hoppy bitterness and a slightly thinner, lightly roasted, smoky bittersweet finish.  Fairly well-balanced and quite drinkable.

12 oz bottle. Poured thick and black with orange highlights. Head was tan with good retention and lacing. Pleasant roasty peated malt aroma. Medium bodied and dry on the tongue. Very earthy flavor dominated by peated malt with a hint of dark chocolate. Good stout.
Has a little bit of smoke in the aroma.Pours black with a medium tan head.Lots of smoke in the flavor.Medium mouthfeel with a smokey finish.

Bottle from brewblackhole.  Smoked malt makes up the majority of the aroma.  Appearance is stout-like--no surprise there.  Creamy, medium palate supports a roasted malt and smoked flavor.  Slightly tangy off flavor in the finish.  Not too bad.

Dark color.  Smell of leather, smoke, licorice, malt, chocolate and hints of coffee.  Tastes like a backyard BBQ.  Lots of smoke, leather, coffee, chocolate and hops.  Very heavy on the smoke flavor.  It was nice and creamy too.

This beer pours an inky black with a plentiful dark tan head. Aroma is of chocolate, and little else. Flavor is light meaty smokiness (like a ham?) which reminded me of an OFallon Smoked Porter I had awhile back. Very interesting. Mouthfeel is a bit thin, but this beer is still fairly drinkable.

Description on the bottle says it all. Sweet maltiness with hints of smoke, taste is dark chocolate, quickly overcome by tastey smoke, very light but very distinct.not bad at all, a nice light bodied smoke brew

12 oz bottle
This is the newest release from Furthermore.  I just now got around to rating it - it actually has been out for a few months now.  Im not sure if this will be a seasonal or a year round release.  Either way it is not too bad.  While not the best in style it is reasonably well done.  I hope Furthermore can stick around long enough to expand their releases even more.
Aroma / Appearance - A deep brown almost black body reminded me of a flat Pepsi.  On top was a tan colored head with little lacing.  The nose was well done.  A base of roasted malts was complimented with smoke, peat, raspberries, coconut and chocolate shavings.
Flavor / Palate - There were no suprises in the first sip.  Smoke, malt, peat and a trace of watermelon rind form the initial impression.  The next couple of sips remind me of vanilla ice cream covered with some Hersheys chocolate syrup.  Towards the end it takes on an oaty character.  The mouthfeel is a little thin but not too bad for the style.  The earthy aftertaste is a little unusual but hardly a turnoff.  This is a solid well made beer which will hopefully survive in the Wisconsin beer landscape.

Pours dark mahogany with a holding, cream-colored head. Heavily smoked aroma... peaty & earthen with chocolate beneath low esters. Fizzy mouthfeel, a little thin. Smoke is prominent above a base of timid malts in the flavor. Alcohol seems very forward to me.<font size=-4>Thanks to <a href=http://www.ratebeer.com/View-User-18266.htm&g for bringing this to the <a href=http://www.ratebeer.com/events-detail.asp?eve "Monthly" 
Chicagoland Ratebeer Gathering</font>

12 oz bottle from Rileys in Madison, WI (December 2006) served around cellar temperature in a Samuel Smith pint glass.  An enormous billowy dark tan head forms above the translucent black walnut body, large bubbles breaking up audibly as the foam descends slowly leaving thick lacing; gorgeous.....light grapy notes are evident upon the cap being popped, but closer nosings show a much more typical bitter cocoa/espresso bean aroma, with fine hints of baked pecans as well; very expressive and well-developed.....doesnt hold up in the body, though its not bad overall, lightly sweet at the front with cocoa, vanilla and a bit of maple, drying out fairly quickly and becoming rather intensely bitter at the very finish....the problem is in the mouthfeel, at once rather thin and watery, and cardboardy towards the end....a little bit of finishing lactic sourness doesnt help either, spoiling an excellent beginning and making this just "good" rather than excellent.

#945, From the bottle, had at the December 06 Chicago Gathering at ElGauchos Place. Clear dark brown with a bit of amber / rubyness to it. Nose is is mossy kind of , malty and sour. Tatse has one heck fo a kick of smoke with a sharp hoppy sting towards the end.

Nice brown color. Decent head. Nose is pleasantly smoky but subdued enough to be subtle. However, the smoke starts to cloy as the beer is tasted w/ an unpleasant peaty not becoming readily apparent. The carbonation is slightly too vigorous but not so much as it overrides the malty notes in the background.

I usually find Dry Stouts to be a dull kind of a drink, but this had that something extra to make it more enjoyable.  Peat smoke.  The bodys a clear dark brown with ruby highlights and sports a respectable ecru head.  The aroma holds notes of roasted malts, roasted barley, and an appreciable whiff of peat smoke.  Its a very dry drink and has the addition of some bittersweet chocolate in the flavor.  It finished on a roasted, dry, smokey note.  Not too shabby.<font size=-4>Drunk at the <a href=http://www.ratebeer.com/events-detail.asp?eve Chicago RateBeerian Gathering thanks to <a href=http://www.ratebeer.com/ViewUser.asp?UserID=1 size=-1>

Bottle. Nice, dry, smoked aroma. Almost opaque body; can see some red when held up to light. Head is pretty light in color for a beer this dark. Nice head. Tight bubble. Initially quite carbonated. Mellows after a few minutes and its nowhere near as carbonated as a lot of Belgian brews youll run across. I like this beer. Smoke is done well. Somewhat dry. Unique. Get your hands on some of this.

Bottle.  Clear dark brown body.  Tangy acidic roast and chocolaty peat in the aroma.  Strong but a bit too acidic for me.  The flavor has a good balance of chocolate sweetness, black patent char, and tangy peat.  A novel addition to an already good dry stout!

Thanks Dave.  The beer pours to a deep black body with a foamy tan head.  A huge roasty charred aroma leaps out of the glass.  Light peat.  The flavor is interesting.  Dry roasty charred black malts with some lightly smoked peat.  Dry roasted palate that finishes lightly tart.

Reddish brown, light brown. 
Slightly burnt malt. Coffee. Okay aroma. 
Flavor is kind of a basic stout thing, with a little sweetness. A little peat. Okay, average stout.

ours a black color w/ a thick tan head and some nice lacing.  A nice dry stout aroma well roasted malts and grains and a touch of smoked peat w/ a tiny hint of lactose.  avg pal.  Flavor is very dry w/ a good amount of peat and a light smoke that is dominating the flavor, finishes very dry some roast malts and some lactose.  Pretty decent.

Near black, that when held to the light looks more very dark brown with a glimmer of umber on the edges. After pouring and entering the beer in the D.B. there is still a small lid of creamy tan bubbles. Roasted malts whirl about with earth and peat in the aroma. Hints of sourdough bread pique the interest. Dry roast flavor start that continues to get sweeter the deeper you enter. Dry lightly acidic finish that continues in the linger. A smokey dryness lingers in the mouth and begs for another sip. I could set at the pub for sometime watching the great games today and knowing my Badgers will only have one lose this year and not have to worry about a BCS bid because the Big Ten Rules!
